Shades of Richard Harding Davis will once more stalk the Barnstormer's stage this year. "The
Dictator," a three-act comedy by
this eminent author, has been selected by the play reading committee of the Barnstormers Club for
this organization's annual presentation at the Lyric Theatre.
Four years ago the Barnstormers
successfully presented "The Galloper," another- play written by
Richard Harding Davis. An interesting fact of this playwright's life
is that he was a member of the undergraduate department at Hopkins
from 1884 to 1886.

YES and NO
He sat there, with his elbow on the table and the right side
of his face in his cupped hand, gazing off rather peaceably into
the misty distances over the librarian's desk, somewhere near the
clock. He looked enviously untroubled and tranquil. From time
to time as we glanced up we noted that his head was moving in a
rhythmical sway but his face was still in the direction of the clock
so that we concluded that he was probably listening to the still sad
music of humanity, listening inwardly to the music of the spheres,
or perhaps composing verse of a nature so excruciatingly exotic
that even the murmur in the library must have been a profanity.
A fellow student sauntered up behind the dreamer and unceremoniously clapped him on the back. The movement was extraordinary, that is on the part of the clapee. He moved rapidly and
precipitately in a northerly direction, I mean he jumped. Then a
most unpoetic line or so wandered across the space to us about
why in hell someone didn't stop that sort of thing!! A moment
or so later we caught his vagrant eye, and further completed the
downfall of lofty thoughts by vulgarly winking at him, an unseemly act to be sure, but enacted in good faith. But even as he
returned the wink we caught the gleam that betokens the writing
fever in his open eye. About fifteen minutes later he presented
us with the following as an answer to our plea in last issue of
Yes and No. Whereupon he returned, slowly but with an even
motion, to his chair and reveries. And how we of the seven
courses envied him!!

E. E. ADAMS
BARN CAFETERIA

A DISTURBING MINORITY
College men, taken as a whole, have a standard of conduct
higher than the average. At all times and places compliance with
this code is expected; on the college grounds one is perfectly
justified in demanding it. This applies not only to the daily
routine of classes and activities, but also to functions of any nature whatever which are given with the official sanction of the
college authorities, for at such affairs the University is largely
judged by the conduct of individuals. Sentiment at Hopkins has
always favored gentlemanly, thoughtful conduct. It still does,
but the action of a few individuals of late might lead to an incorrect impression.
To be specific, we refer to drinking at the dances given in
the Civil Engineering Hall by the Cotillon Board. In the first
place, bringing liquor on the University grounds is absolutely
forbidden. From the point of view of general policy, and more
recently of constitutionality, the wisdom and necessity of such a
ruling is so apparent that there has never been any need of calling attention to it. We mentioned it here, however, to dispel
any possible misunderstanding. There are only a few rules laid
down by the University authorities, but those few cannot be
broken with impunity. This word to the wise should be sufficient.
From a strictly undergraduate point of view, the question is
just as serious. We hold no brief against drinking in itself; there
are occasions when it is permissible and perhaps even appropriate,
but a Hopkins dance, especially on Hopkins grounds is not one
of them. This applies to what might be termed moderate drinking. Absolute drunkenness is difficult to condone under any circumstances; at a University dance it should not be tolerated for
an instant.
At the recent dances given in the evening, especially at the
one last Thursday, drinking was entirely too much in evidence.
Not all of the blame can be laid on members of the University,
since some of the chief offenders were alumni or outsiders. The
final responsibility, however, rests with the Cotillon Board for
admitting them. As a matter of fact, the board seems to be responsible for nearly all of the trouble. The small number of men
who cause trouble by drinking at the dances could be easily controlled by the board, which is in charge; instead of taking any
action, some of its members go to the other extreme and themselves set a bad example.
It seems to us that the inefficiency of the Cotillon Board has
been due merely to thoughtlessness and failure to realize its responsibility. Upon a little reflection, they should be able to handle
the situation satisfactorily. If they are not, some more drastic
measures will have to be taken to make Hopkins dances worthy
of the best traditions of the University.

Our First Contribution
Sometimes I feel poetic. But it is difficult to write poetry,
which immediately sort of queers my fun in being poetic. And
anyway if one writes poetry one must be poetic about something,
like a tree or someone's kisses or maybe a muse or so. However,
I do like to write but I always remember uncomfortably that someone said, I can't remember who, that someone else never wrote,
because primarily he had nothing to say and if he had he wouldn't
know how to say it. Being less discreet, however, I plow ahead,
no purpose in view, somewhat like Dr. Mitchell's lecture, you
know. Pardon me, sir! Do they ever ventilate the library?
Couldn't we advocate a male librarian or least a nice husky lady
who might let in a bit of air intermittently? Dr. Boazz will have
to stop being so amusing. I had only three hours sleep last night
and I don't think I rested at all well in his class this morning.
But Mr. Uhler has a splendid drone, and oh! how comfortable
the seats in the rear of his classroom. Yes, she is good looking
and reading a German magazine—in my ignorance I must enquire
whether the Germans settled in Spain or the Spanish in Germany,
else how account for the attractive darkness—Oh! my, here's
somebody talking about the party last night! Why don't these
co-eds wear longer dresses, who wants a telescope or didn't anyone
say anything about one? Who writes "Pourboire" and why use
such a title as that? I don't know what it means, and that always
disturbs me, why not call it "Smatterings" or "Bits-o-Nothing" or
anything delightfully inane like that. I'm always so disappointed
to start to read the column, not expecting to understand a word of
it—and then find it so simple. Well I must sleep!
C. P. A.,'27.

YES and NO
He sat there, with his elbow on the table and the right side
of his face in his cupped hand, gazing off rather peaceably into
the misty distances over the librarian's desk, somewhere near the
clock. He looked enviously untroubled and tranquil. From time
to time as we glanced up we noted that his head was moving in a
rhythmical sway but his face was still in the direction of the clock
so that we concluded that he was probably listening to the still sad
music of humanity, listening inwardly to the music of the spheres,
or perhaps composing verse of a nature so excruciatingly exotic
that even the murmur in the library must have been a profanity.
A fellow student sauntered up behind the dreamer and unceremoniously clapped him on the back. The movement was extraordinary, that is on the part of the clapee. He moved rapidly and
precipitately in a northerly direction, I mean he jumped. Then a
most unpoetic line or so wandered across the space to us about
why in hell someone didn't stop that sort of thing!! A moment
or so later we caught his vagrant eye, and further completed the
downfall of lofty thoughts by vulgarly winking at him, an unseemly act to be sure, but enacted in good faith. But even as he
returned the wink we caught the gleam that betokens the writing
fever in his open eye. About fifteen minutes later he presented
us with the following as an answer to our plea in last issue of
Yes and No. Whereupon he returned, slowly but with an even
motion, to his chair and reveries. And how we of the seven
courses envied him!!

E. E. ADAMS

A DISTURBING MINORITY
College men, taken as a whole, have a standard of conduct
higher than the average. At all times and places compliance with
this code is expected; on the college grounds one is perfectly
justified in demanding it. This applies not only to the daily
routine of classes and activities, but also to functions of any nature whatever which are given with the official sanction of the
college authorities, for at such affairs the University is largely
judged by the conduct of individuals. Sentiment at Hopkins has
always favored gentlemanly, thoughtful conduct. It still does,
but the action of a few individuals of late might lead to an incorrect impression.
To be specific, we refer to drinking at the dances given in
the Civil Engineering Hall by the Cotillon Board. In the first
place, bringing liquor on the University grounds is absolutely
forbidden. From the point of view of general policy, and more
recently of constitutionality, the wisdom and necessity of such a
ruling is so apparent that there has never been any need of calling attention to it. We mentioned it here, however, to dispel
any possible misunderstanding. There are only a few rules laid
down by the University authorities, but those few cannot be
broken with impunity. This word to the wise should be sufficient.
From a strictly undergraduate point of view, the question is
just as serious. We hold no brief against drinking in itself; there
are occasions when it is permissible and perhaps even appropriate,
but a Hopkins dance, especially on Hopkins grounds is not one
of them. This applies to what might be termed moderate drinking. Absolute drunkenness is difficult to condone under any circumstances; at a University dance it should not be tolerated for
an instant.
At the recent dances given in the evening, especially at the
one last Thursday, drinking was entirely too much in evidence.
Not all of the blame can be laid on members of the University,
since some of the chief offenders were alumni or outsiders. The
final responsibility, however, rests with the Cotillon Board for
admitting them. As a matter of fact, the board seems to be responsible for nearly all of the trouble. The small number of men
who cause trouble by drinking at the dances could be easily controlled by the board, which is in charge; instead of taking any
action, some of its members go to the other extreme and them-

Our First Contribution
Sometimes I feel poetic. But it is difficult to write poetry,
which immediately sort of queers my fun in being poetic. And
anyway if one writes poetry one must be poetic about something,
like a tree or someone's kisses or maybe a muse or so. However,
I do like to write but I always remember uncomfortably that someone said, I can't remember who, that someone else never wrote,
because primarily he had nothing to say and if he had he wouldn't
know how to say it. Being less discreet, however, I plow ahead,
no purpose in view, somewhat like Dr. Mitchell's lecture, you
know. Pardon me, sir! Do they ever ventilate the library?
Couldn't we advocate a male librarian or least a nice husky lady
who might let in a bit of air intermittently? Dr. Boazz will have
to stop being so amusing. I had only three hours sleep last night
and I don't think I rested at all well in his class this morning.
But Mr. Uhler has a splendid drone, and oh! how comfortable
the seats in the rear of his classroom. Yes, she is good looking
and reading a German magazine—in my ignorance I must enquire
whether the Germans settled in Spain or the Spanish in Germany,
else how account for the attractive darkness—Oh! my, here's
somebody talking about the party last night! Why don't these
co-eds wear longer dresses, who wants a telescope or didn't anyone
say anything about one? Who writes "Pourboire" and why use
such a title as that? I don't know what it means, and that always
disturbs me, why not call it "Smatterings" or "Bits-o-Nothing" or
anything delightfully inane like that. I'm always so disappointed
to start to read the column, not expecting to understand a word of
it—and then find it so simple. Well I must sleep!
C. P. A.,'27.

Two North Dakota colleges have
refused to debate in favor of the
amendment of the Volstead law.
Dakota Wesleyan University and
Northern State Teachers College
were recently notified by Pi Kappa
Delta, National Forensic Society,
that they were to prepare teams to
debate the affirmative of "Resolved,
That the Volstead Law be amended
to permit the sale of light wines
and beer."
Dakota Wesleyan refused to argue the question while the team of
the Teachers College boldly declared that "this college stands for
law enforcement."

According to the McGill Daily,
students in German universities
take but one examination in four
years. The German scholars, however, are required to concentrate in
but one field of knowledge and are
allowed no cuts.
Straight-laced Puritanism seems
to be the rule at the new John Wesley College at Cambiia, Illinois.
Not only are fraternities, dances,
student government and athletics
forbidden, but every entering student is also required to sign a
Pledge to refrain from tobacco and
liquor.

Sixty-five windows were shattered at the Virginia Polytechnic
Institute several weeks ago when a
couple of the more playful students
set off a charge of dynamite on the
campus. The guilty ones claimed
that they were only playing a practical joke. The result of the episode, however, has turned out to be
very impractical for the students,
since they must pay for the damage at the rate of fifty cents a pane.

THE NEWS-LETTER

MAILBAG
UP AND AT 'EM!
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
It has been said that the pen is
mightier than the sword. But if the
result produced by the pen is nil,
what then the sword? Do minus
quantities exist for journalism as
well as calculus?
Certainly enthusiasm on the part
of the undergraduates with regard
to the Student Activities Building
appears to be a negative quantity.
Will such a situation continue? Will
the pledges of $115,000 toward the
necessary $170,000 be carelessly
thrown away? Will the student
body ignore the opportunity to occupy more commodious, yea, even luxurious quarters than the Barn can
ever afford?
Furthermore, what has happened
to the committee elected by the students to co-operate with the representatives of the Administration?
Its members are all with us, but idle
on this subject. Student opinion is
lethargic; active student support a
myth. It is high time for action.
•
Doggedly,
RusTicus.

a couple. The entire school is invited.

YES and NO
He sat there, with his elbow on the table and the right side
of his face in his cupped hand, gazing off rather peaceably into
the misty distances over the librarian's desk, somewhere near the
clock. He looked enviously untroubled and tranquil. From time
to time as we glanced up we noted that his head was moving in a
rhythmical sway but his face was still in the direction of the clock
so that we concluded that he was probably listening to the still sad
music of humanity, listening inwardly to the music of the spheres,
or perhaps composing verse of a nature so excruciatingly exotic
that even the murmur in the library must have been a profanity.
A fellow student sauntered up behind the dreamer and unceremoniously clapped him on the back. The movement was extraordinary, that is on the part of the clapee. He moved rapidly and
precipitately in a northerly direction, I mean he jumped. Then a
most unpoetic line or so wandered across the space to us about
why in hell someone didn't stop that sort of thing!! A moment
or so later we caught his vagrant eye, and further completed the
downfall of lofty thoughts by vulgarly winking at him, an unseemly act to be sure, but enacted in good faith. But even as he
returned the wink we caught the gleam that betokens the writing
fever in his open eye. About fifteen minutes later he presented
us with the following as an answer to our plea in last issue of
Yes and No. Whereupon he returned, slowly but with an even
motion, to his chair and reveries. And how we of the seven
courses envied him!!

E. E. ADAMS

A DISTURBING MINORITY
College men, taken as a whole, have a standard of conduct
higher than the average. At all times and places compliance with
this code is expected; on the college grounds one is perfectly
justified in demanding it. This applies not only to the daily
routine of classes and activities, but also to functions of any nature whatever which are given with the official sanction of the
college authorities, for at such affairs the University is largely
judged by the conduct of individuals. Sentiment at Hopkins has
always favored gentlemanly, thoughtful conduct. It still does,
but the action of a few individuals of late might lead to an incorrect impression.
To be specific, we refer to drinking at the dances given in
the Civil Engineering Hall by the Cotillon Board. In the first
place, bringing liquor on the University grounds is absolutely
forbidden. From the point of view of general policy, and more
recently of constitutionality, the wisdom and necessity of such a
ruling is so apparent that there has never been any need of calling attention to it. We mentioned it here, however, to dispel
any possible misunderstanding. There are only a few rules laid
down by the University authorities, but those few cannot be
broken with impunity. This word to the wise should be sufficient.
From a strictly undergraduate point of view, the question is
just as serious. We hold no brief against drinking in itself; there
are occasions when it is permissible and perhaps even appropriate,
but a Hopkins dance, especially on Hopkins grounds is not one
of them. This applies to what might be termed moderate drinking. Absolute drunkenness is difficult to condone under any circumstances; at a University dance it should not be tolerated for
an instant.
At the recent dances given in the evening, especially at the
one last Thursday, drinking was entirely too much in evidence.
Not all of the blame can be laid on members of the University,
since some of the chief offenders were alumni or outsiders. The
final responsibility, however, rests with the Cotillon Board for
admitting them. As a matter of fact, the board seems to be responsible for nearly all of the trouble. The small number of men
who cause trouble by drinking at the dances could be easily controlled by the board, which is in charge; instead of taking any
action, some of its members go to the other extreme and themselves set a bad example.
It seems to us that the inefficiency of the Cotillon Board has
been due merely to thoughtlessness and failure to realize its responsibility. Upon a little reflection, they should be able to handle
the situation satisfactorily. If they are not, some more drastic
measures will have to be taken to make Hopkins dances worthy
of the best traditions of the University.

Our First Contribution
Sometimes I feel poetic. But it is difficult to write poetry,
which immediately sort of queers my fun in being poetic. And
anyway if one writes poetry one must be poetic about something,
like a tree or someone's kisses or maybe a muse or so. However,
I do like to write but I always remember uncomfortably that someone said, I can't remember who, that someone else never wrote,
because primarily he had nothing to say and if he had he wouldn't
know how to say it. Being less discreet, however, I plow ahead,
no purpose in view, somewhat like Dr. Mitchell's lecture, you
know. Pardon me, sir! Do they ever ventilate the library?
Couldn't we advocate a male librarian or least a nice husky lady
who might let in a bit of air intermittently? Dr. Boazz will have
to stop being so amusing. I had only three hours sleep last night
and I don't think I rested at all well in his class this morning.
But Mr. Uhler has a splendid drone, and oh! how comfortable
the seats in the rear of his classroom. Yes, she is good looking
and reading a German magazine—in my ignorance I must enquire
whether the Germans settled in Spain or the Spanish in Germany,
else how account for the attractive darkness—Oh! my, here's
somebody talking about the party last night! Why don't these
co-eds wear longer dresses, who wants a telescope or didn't anyone
say anything about one? Who writes "Pourboire" and why use
such a title as that? I don't know what it means, and that always
disturbs me, why not call it "Smatterings" or "Bits-o-Nothing" or
anything delightfully inane like that. I'm always so disappointed
to start to read the column, not expecting to understand a word of
it—and then find it so simple. Well I must sleep!
C. P. A.,'27.

YES and NO
He sat there, with his elbow on the table and the right side
of his face in his cupped hand, gazing off rather peaceably into
the misty distances over the librarian's desk, somewhere near the
clock. He looked enviously untroubled and tranquil. From time
to time as we glanced up we noted that his head was moving in a
rhythmical sway but his face was still in the direction of the clock
so that we concluded that he was probably listening to the still sad
music of humanity, listening inwardly to the music of the spheres,
or perhaps composing verse of a nature so excruciatingly exotic
that even the murmur in the library must have been a profanity.
A fellow student sauntered up behind the dreamer and unceremoniously clapped him on the back. The movement was extraordinary, that is on the part of the clapee. He moved rapidly and
precipitately in a northerly direction, I mean he jumped. Then a
most unpoetic line or so wandered across the space to us about
why in hell someone didn't stop that sort of thing!! A moment
or so later we caught his vagrant eye, and further completed the
downfall of lofty thoughts by vulgarly winking at him, an unseemly act to be sure, but enacted in good faith. But even as he
returned the wink we caught the gleam that betokens the writing
fever in his open eye. About fifteen minutes later he presented
us with the following as an answer to our plea in last issue of
Yes and No. Whereupon he returned, slowly but with an even
motion, to his chair and reveries. And how we of the seven
courses envied him!!

E. E. ADAMS

A DISTURBING MINORITY
College men, taken as a whole, have a standard of conduct
higher than the average. At all times and places compliance with
this code is expected; on the college grounds one is perfectly
justified in demanding it. This applies not only to the daily
routine of classes and activities, but also to functions of any nature whatever which are given with the official sanction of the
college authorities, for at such affairs the University is largely
judged by the conduct of individuals. Sentiment at Hopkins has
always favored gentlemanly, thoughtful conduct. It still does,
but the action of a few individuals of late might lead to an incorrect impression.
To be specific, we refer to drinking at the dances given in
the Civil Engineering Hall by the Cotillon Board. In the first
place, bringing liquor on the University grounds is absolutely
forbidden. From the point of view of general policy, and more
recently of constitutionality, the wisdom and necessity of such a
ruling is so apparent that there has never been any need of calling attention to it. We mentioned it here, however, to dispel
any possible misunderstanding. There are only a few rules laid
down by the University authorities, but those few cannot be
broken with impunity. This word to the wise should be sufficient.
From a strictly undergraduate point of view, the question is
just as serious. We hold no brief against drinking in itself; there
are occasions when it is permissible and perhaps even appropriate,
but a Hopkins dance, especially on Hopkins grounds is not one
of them. This applies to what might be termed moderate drinking. Absolute drunkenness is difficult to condone under any circumstances; at a University dance it should not be tolerated for
an instant.
At the recent dances given in the evening, especially at the
one last Thursday, drinking was entirely too much in evidence.
Not all of the blame can be laid on members of the University,
since some of the chief offenders were alumni or outsiders. The
final responsibility, however, rests with the Cotillon Board for
admitting them. As a matter of fact, the board seems to be responsible for nearly all of the trouble. The small number of men
who cause trouble by drinking at the dances could be easily controlled by the board, which is in charge; instead of taking any
action, some of its members go to the other extreme and them-

Our First Contribution
Sometimes I feel poetic. But it is difficult to write poetry,
which immediately sort of queers my fun in being poetic. And
anyway if one writes poetry one must be poetic about something,
like a tree or someone's kisses or maybe a muse or so. However,
I do like to write but I always remember uncomfortably that someone said, I can't remember who, that someone else never wrote,
because primarily he had nothing to say and if he had he wouldn't
know how to say it. Being less discreet, however, I plow ahead,
no purpose in view, somewhat like Dr. Mitchell's lecture, you
know. Pardon me, sir! Do they ever ventilate the library?
Couldn't we advocate a male librarian or least a nice husky lady
who might let in a bit of air intermittently? Dr. Boazz will have
to stop being so amusing. I had only three hours sleep last night
and I don't think I rested at all well in his class this morning.
But Mr. Uhler has a splendid drone, and oh! how comfortable
the seats in the rear of his classroom. Yes, she is good looking
and reading a German magazine—in my ignorance I must enquire
whether the Germans settled in Spain or the Spanish in Germany,
else how account for the attractive darkness—Oh! my, here's
somebody talking about the party last night! Why don't these
co-eds wear longer dresses, who wants a telescope or didn't anyone
say anything about one? Who writes "Pourboire" and why use
such a title as that? I don't know what it means, and that always
disturbs me, why not call it "Smatterings" or "Bits-o-Nothing" or
anything delightfully inane like that. I'm always so disappointed
to start to read the column, not expecting to understand a word of
it—and then find it so simple. Well I must sleep!
C. P. A.,'27.

Two North Dakota colleges have
refused to debate in favor of the
amendment of the Volstead law.
Dakota Wesleyan University and
Northern State Teachers College
were recently notified by Pi Kappa
Delta, National Forensic Society,
that they were to prepare teams to
debate the affirmative of "Resolved,
That the Volstead Law be amended
to permit the sale of light wines
and beer."
Dakota Wesleyan refused to argue the question while the team of
the Teachers College boldly declared that "this college stands for
law enforcement."

According to the McGill Daily,
students in German universities
take but one examination in four
years. The German scholars, however, are required to concentrate in
but one field of knowledge and are
allowed no cuts.
Straight-laced Puritanism seems
to be the rule at the new John Wesley College at Cambiia, Illinois.
Not only are fraternities, dances,
student government and athletics
forbidden, but every entering student is also required to sign a
Pledge to refrain from tobacco and
liquor.

MAILBAG
UP AND AT 'EM!
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
It has been said that the pen is
mightier than the sword. But if the
result produced by the pen is nil,
what then the sword? Do minus
quantities exist for journalism as
well as calculus?
Certainly enthusiasm on the part
of the undergraduates with regard
to the Student Activities Building
appears to be a negative quantity.
Will such a situation continue? Will
the pledges of $115,000 toward the
necessary $170,000 be carelessly
thrown away? Will the student
body ignore the opportunity to occupy more commodious, yea, even luxurious quarters than the Barn can
ever afford?
Furthermore, what has happened
to the committee elected by the students to co-operate with the representatives of the Administration?
Its members are all with us, but idle
on this subject. Student opinion is
lethargic; active student support a
myth. It is high time for action.
•
Doggedly,
RusTicus.
